posts.name: Landon
posts.cooked: I was wondering is there a way to find the distance between two robots using a limelight and then having your robot move to fit in between the two? If anyone has any ideas of where I can start to do this any help, suggestions, or examples of doing this in code would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked: I am not certain about this, but are we assuming they are on the same plane? If so, there seems to potentially be a nice triangle here. If that assumption is correct, would that help you?

posts.name: Landon
posts.cooked: yes, we are assuming they are on the same plane because they will both be relatively in similar positions on the charge station.

posts.name: team5682zs
posts.cooked:
Limelight will find robots? Assuming that you can get the x and y position of the 2 robots, the Pythagorean theorem will give you the distance you are looking for.

I dont know about the data that limelight would give you about another robot, because you would need to know the size of the robot and what the origin of the detected robot is if you want to procedurallycreate a path to the midpoint… (center may not be accurate)

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
I was just writing this, but second guessing myself. Theoretically with the new machine learning algorithm, a limelight can find robots, but you are correct about needing to be on center. There is not a lot of extra space in the middle there.

Also, I was thinking if you were equidistant from them, you may want to split the triangle into two right triangles before assuming you were on the hypotenuse, but I could be wrong about that.

posts.name: team5682zs
posts.cooked:
If the goal is to auto the endgame, that will come with some unpredictable variables to overcome.  Every robot is different and control system different.

If your using the Neural Detection features to find things you trained as robots, I think you can get the center of the detected “box” as a 3d point in field space. It could be fairly assumed with a limelight (and encoders), you could have good data about your own Field space.

If possible, I would not “b line” it to the midpoint.  But instead find the intersection of two lines.  The first is perpendicular to the pythagorean line beteww the two bots at the midpoint.  And the other a parallel line to that pythagorean line that your robot is on.

But again there is not alot of real estate on that charging station.  If you got field-space, then you can reference the bounds of the charging station as an object in some way.  Maybe if the two bots are close to each other and there is space on one side, an algorithm can plot your path there.

posts.name: team5682zs
posts.cooked: I said the same thing, but in a more complicated way.  It is a good suggestion to Make yourself equidistant from them before getting to the middle.  TrajectoryGenerator in Java or C has this.
